text: for it to work.
When python instantiates a class, it essentially carries out the above procedure for each of the class methods.
When you 'monkey-patch' a method onto an object in the way that you were trying to do it, it's not a bound method and just exists as a function in instance.__dict__.
Calling it is no different than calling any other function.
If you want to stick a method on an instance, you have to manually make it a method as shown above.
If you were to do

code:
class Person(object):
    pass

def say_hi(self):
    print 'hii'

Person.say_hi = say_hi

me = Person()
me.say_hi()

text: then it would work because Python will create the method for you.

Here are the definitions:

code:
>>> class Person(object):
...     def bound(self):
...             print "Hi, I'm bound."
... 
>>> def unbound(self):
...     print "Hi, I'm unbound."

text: Note the types of these methods and functions.
When it gets set on the Person before instantiation, it gets bound.

code:
>>> Person().bound()
Hi, I'm bound.
>>> Person().unbound()
Hi, I'm unbound.

text: However, if it's set after instantiation, it's still of type 'function'.

code:
>>> me = Person()
>>> me.rebound = unbound
>>> type(me.rebound)
<type 'function'>
>>> type(me.unbound)
<type 'instancemethod'>
>>> me.rebound
<function unbound at 0x7fa05efac9b0>
>>> me.rebound()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: unbound() takes exactly 1 argument (0 given)

text: The 'instancemethod' type can be used to bind a 'function' to an object.
It's in the types module as MethodType.

code:
>>> import types
>>> me.rebound = types.MethodType(unbound, me, Person)

text: Now it's bound properly.

code:
>>> type(me.rebound)
<type 'instancemethod'>
>>> me.rebound()
Hi, I'm unbound.

text: The self argument of a method is passed automatically.
You don't have a method, but a function that is an attribute of an object.
If you did Person.say_hi = say_hi, then Person().say_hi() would work as expected.
A method is a function that's attribute of a class, not an instance, and self is passed only for methods.
Class attributes define how the instances should work, while instance attributes are just normal you access.
This means that class attributes are modified when they are accessed from an instance (e.g.
functions are turned into methods), while instance attributes are left unchanged.

code:
>>> class A(object): pass
... 
>>> def f(self): print self
... 
>>> ob = A()
>>> A.f = f
>>> ob.g = f
>>> print ob.f
<bound method A.f of <__main__.A object at 0xb74204ec>>
>>> print ob.g
<function f at 0xb7412ae4>
>>> ob.f()
<__main__.A object at 0xb74204ec>
>>> ob.g('test')
test

text: Since A is a class, f, A().f and A.f are different things.
Since ob is an object, f and ob.g are the same thing.
